thread.title: Review: Chevrolet Volt improves, but not on pizzazz

author: yahoo
title: Review: Chevrolet Volt improves, but not on pizzazz
text:
The all-new 2016 Chevrolet Volt electric car with extended range, showcasing a sleeker, sportier design that offers 50 miles of EV range, greater efficiency and stronger acceleration. (Photo: Chevrolet Volt) 
11 CONNECT 12 TWEET LINKEDIN 6 COMMENT EMAIL MORE SAUSALITO, Calif. -- There's every reason to love the new, second-generation Chevrolet Volt.
The front end of this pioneering, underappreciated plug-in compact has been given a fancier look and the car is more shapely overall. The dashboard doesn't feel like it's trying to imitate a hard-plastic appliance anymore. The gas-powered engine is now quiet enough that it silently take over from battery power without the driver really being able to tell.
We only wish the 2016 Chevy Volt had a little more pizzazz. It's all practicality, no flash.
The new Volt feels like any competent small car. It's quiet, sure-footed and saves tankloads of gas. But don't expect a clot of jealous neighbors to wander over to your driveway with quizzical looks.
The new Volt feels like Chevrolet wanted it to become more mainstream. In the process, it lost some personality. This car was more fun as a brat. Now it's a grown up.
Of course, there's a lot to appreciate about grown ups. Outside, it's less angular, less extreme in appearance. From a distance, it looks like any other well-designed General Motors small car. The appearance is likely to stay fresh, longer.

You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide The Volt has been dressed up. The interior feels more upscale, although a high contrast black-and-tan interior combination wasn't exactly to our liking. There's now a fifth seat -- if the extra rear passenger doesn't straddling the rear hump in back that's part of the T-shaped battery pack.
The dashboard ditches the white or black hard plastic around the center stack like an iPod or coffee maker and now is just dominated by two larger display screens. One is in front of the driver and the other is in the middle.
Besides navigation, audio and climate control, the screens impart information about how the Volt is stacking up on electric range and fuel use. Like Toyota's Prius, it has a screen showing which way the electrons are flowing to help coach drivers toward more gas savings.
The redesigned Volt is a darling for GM engineers, who poured their souls into drawing more range and power from its batteries. The electric only range is now 53 miles before the 1.5-liter gas engine kicks in, what GM says is a nearly 40% improvement. The new electric motors are 12% more efficient and 100 pounds lighter than the outgoing model.
Driving around the hills north of San Francisco, we tried to drain the car's batteries over a long afternoon -- and couldn't. The car always seemed to have reserve electricity, recharging itself during braking.
Between the juice and gas engine, the new Chevy Volt has a range of 420 miles. In everyday commuting, with owners charging the car in the garage ever night, Chevy officials say most will go 1,000 miles between visits to the filling station.
With those kind of numbers, even in times of low gas prices, you'd think that Chevrolet Volt would have sold better. GM says it has put 80,000 of them on the streets since it went on sale for the 2011 model year. That's not a lot considering the high expectations GM once had for it. This year, GM sold 9,264 through the first three quarters of the year, down 36.3% from a year ago.
It won't help that the new one, which is just coming to dealerships, will be limited in sales to California, Oregon and some East Coast states until supplies build. "We're going where customer demand is," says Steve Majoros, Chevrolet's marketing director.
Chevrolet is held back by its relative high price -- $33,995 including destination charges but before up to $7,500 in federal tax incentives. The Volt starts at twice the price of the conventionally powered and similarly sized Chevy Cruze. But at the same time, Volt is about half the price of the cheapest Tesla Model S.
At least Volt has become a mainstay of the Chevrolet lineup, not a knee-jerk reaction to chaotic gas prices. It's now a "poster child" for GM's high-tech prowess, Majoros says. Pizzazz? That's another matter.
"It's done everything we've wanted the car to do in its category," he says.
What Stands Out 
•Hush: Engine or battery, both are quiet
•Range: 420 miles between electricity and gas
•Interior: Updated, but black-and-tan hurts the eyes
2016 Chevrolet Volt 
•What? The new version of the extended-range electric sedan
•When? Coming to dealers in California, Oregon and some Eastern states, with the rest of the nation to follow
•Where? Made in Hamtramck, Mich.
•How much: $33,995, including $825 shipping
•What makes it go? A 18.4-kilowatt lithium-ion battery backed up by a 1.5-liter gas engine
•How big? 15 feet long
•How thirsty? Up to 53 miles of electric driving. The backup gas engine is rated at 42 miles per gallon in combined city and highway driving. The government mile-per-gallon equivalent is 106 MPGe.
•Overall: It will set engineers' brains on fire, probably not hearts
